title: How to Prepare Mushrooms

steps.headline: Wet a paper towel or soft mushroom brush for non-morel mushrooms.
steps.description: You don’t want to get most mushrooms too wet when cleaning them, so soaking them is a bad idea. Instead, dampen a paper towel or soft mushroom brush at the sink. Squeeze the paper towel or shake off the brush to remove any excess moisture.

steps.headline: Wipe the mushrooms one at a time.
steps.description: When the paper towel or brush is damp, gently wipe down each mushroom. Work with a single mushroom at a time to ensure that you remove as much of the dirt as possible.

steps.headline: Lightly rinse especially dirty mushrooms at the sink.
steps.description: If the mushrooms seem particularly dirty, you can give them a quick rinse under running water. Make sure that the water is cool, and keep the stream light to avoid oversaturating the mushrooms. Again, be careful not to soak the mushrooms, or they’ll absorb too much water and won’t brown properly when you cook them.

steps.headline: Dry the mushrooms with clean paper towel.
steps.description: Once the mushrooms are clean, use a piece of clean paper towel to dry them. Pat them gently to remove the excess moisture.

steps.headline: Cut and trim morels.
steps.description: Morels mushrooms need to be cleaned a little differently than other mushrooms. Start by using a sharp knife to cut a thin slice off the bottom of the stems. Next, cut the mushrooms in half from stem to tip if you’d like.

steps.headline: Rinse morels under cool water.
steps.description: After you’ve cut and trimmed the morels, run them under the sink to remove any dirt or insects. If the mushrooms still look dirty after rinsing, fill a bowl with cool water and a pinch of salt, and soak the morels for 10 to 20 minutes to remove the remaining dirt and debris. Agitate the morels periodically while they’re soaking to help loosen the dirt. Change the water as necessary while the morels are soaking. If you notice it becoming dirty, dump it out and add fresh, cool water. Add another pinch of salt as well.

steps.headline: Pat the morels dry.
steps.description: Once the morels are clean, use a clean paper towel to dry them thoroughly. Because they’ve already been cut, you can use them immediately or store them in the fridge.

steps.headline: Trim the mushroom stems.
steps.description: When the mushrooms are clean, place them on a cutting board or other safe cutting surface. Use a sharp knife to cut off the mushrooms’ stems. This removes the woody, dried out part of the mushrooms and creates a flat base that makes it easier to slice or chop them.

steps.headline: Cut the mushrooms into halves.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the stems, use the knife to cut the mushrooms down the center. Depending on the recipe that you’re using, you may want to then quarter them. When you’re cutting mushrooms, avoid using a serrated knife, which can tear at the mushrooms.

steps.headline: Slice or chop the mushrooms as the recipe dictates.
steps.description: When the mushrooms are halved, use the knife to cut them as your recipe requires. Some may call for thin slices, while others may require chopped or diced mushrooms.

steps.headline: Twist the stems off the mushrooms.
steps.description: If you’re making stuffed mushrooms, you don’t need to cut them first. Hold the mushroom with one hand, and use the other hand to gently twist the stem to snap it off. When it comes to stuffing mushrooms, large white, cremini, and portobello varieties work best. You can reserve the stems to use in the stuffing for the mushrooms. Mince or finely chop them if you plan to use them.

steps.headline: Scoop out the gills from under portobello mushrooms.
steps.description: Portobello mushrooms require a little extra preparation for stuffing. After you twist off their stems, hold the mushrooms in one hand, and use a spoon to gently scrape out all the gills from the underside. Throw away the gills.

steps.headline: Fill each mushroom with your desired stuffing.
steps.description: When you’ve removed the stems and gills if necessary, the mushrooms are ready for filling. Add a spoonful of your desired stuffing and cook according to your recipe.

steps.headline: Saute mushrooms.
steps.description: Sauteed mushrooms can make a tasty side dish or topping for sandwiches. Heat about 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of olive oil over medium heat for 5 minutes, and then add some mushrooms and a pinch of salt. Cook the mushrooms for 10 minutes or until they're golden brown. You can substitute butter for the olive oil if you prefer.

steps.headline: Mix mushrooms into soup.
steps.description: Mushrooms can add a nice meaty flavor and texture to your favorite soup. Start by sauteeing the mushrooms to cook some of the excess moisture out of them. Next, add them to your favorite soup base about 10 to 15 minutes before it should be done to ensure that they don't get soggy.

steps.headline: Add mushrooms to tomato-based pasta sauce.
steps.description: Mushrooms can give simple pasta sauce a rich, earthy flavor. Saute the mushrooms in olive oil with onions and garlic over medium heat for 5 to 7 minutes or until the vegetables are softened. Next, add the ingredients for your favorite pasta sauce, such as a can of crushed tomatoes, wine, and fresh herbs, and cook according to the recipe. You can also toss sauteed mushrooms into a finished pasta dish with any pasta sauce that you like.

steps.headline: Look for firm, plump mushrooms.
steps.description: This indicates that they’re fresh. If they’re mushy or shriveled, they may be spoiled. Avoid mushrooms that have bruises, spots, or a slimy texture. If you’re buying white mushrooms, make sure that the gills on the underside are tightly closed.

steps.headline: Place unwashed mushrooms in non-plastic packaging for storage.
steps.description: For all mushrooms except morels, you should wait until you’re going to use them to wash them. Leave the mushrooms in their original packaging or transfer them to a paper bag. Avoid plastic bags because they don’t allow the mushrooms to breathe. Morels should be washed before storing. Wrap the cleaned morels in a damp paper towel, and set them in a bowl for storage.

steps.headline: Store the mushrooms in the refrigerator for 2 days.
steps.description: Most mushrooms typically stay fresh for up to 2 days. You'll know that they've gone bad if they start to get mushy or slimy. Morel mushrooms will stay fresh in the refrigerator for up to the 3 days, though you need to keep the paper towel around them damp.
